I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
(i) policy-based grant and (ii) a project grant, both to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Power 
Sector Development Program. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA)—
Preparing and Implementing Gender-Inclusive Projects in Central and West Asia, Subproject 4: 
Empowering Women in the Power Sector in Tajikistan—and if the Board approves the proposed 
grants, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The proposed program will intensify the implementation of ongoing reforms and improve 
the financial sustainability of the power subsector in Tajikistan.1 The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  has  supported  Tajikistan’s  power  subsector  reforms  since  2012  through  the  sector 
operational performance improvement (SOPI) program, a component of the Regional Power 
Transmission Project.2 The SOPI program built the basis for the proposed fundamental reforms, 
which  include  unbundling  the  vertically  integrated  power  utility,  restructuring  its  excessive 
liabilities, establishing a regulator, adopting a tariff methodology, and setting up a new centralized 
cash control system among the unbundled entities. As a part of the reforms and institutional 
capacity building, a newly established power distribution company will be operated under a 5-year 
management contract. Investments in retail advanced metering infrastructure in Dushanbe, the 
nation's capital, and six other cities will fill the key deficiencies in the subsector’s power loss 
accounting and bill collection systems.3  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Macroeconomic context. Tajikistan’s gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 
7.1% during 2016–2019. The fiscal deficit spiked in 2017 to 6.0% of GDP as the government 
increased borrowing to recapitalize state-owned banks left insolvent by the 2015 financial crisis 
and to boost capital expenditures for the Rogun hydropower project.4 As the Rogun expenditures 
became more contained, the government brought the fiscal deficit under control, to 2.8% of GDP 
in 2018 and 2.1% in 2019. Before the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the fiscal deficit 
was projected to rise to 5.2% of GDP in 2020 and stabilize at 4% on average in 2021–2022. Public 
debt was on a downward trend from a peak of 50.4% of GDP in 2017 to 44.6% in 2019. The 
current account deficit also narrowed from 5.0% of GDP in 2018 to 2.3% in 2019. The government 
has been implementing (i) public financial management reforms, supported by ADB and other 
development partners, to improve fiscal management; and (ii) reforms to state-owned enterprises 
in the power subsector to improve their performance and corporate governance, and reduce 
losses and fiscal risks. While Tajikistan had been categorized as being at high risk of debt distress 
by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) since 2017, the IMF’s analysis in 2020 concluded that 
the  country’s  public  debt  is  sustainable.  ADB  also  assessed  that  Tajikistan's  overall 
macroeconomic management is generally sound.5

4.  Impact of COVID-19 in 2020. However, the COVID-19 pandemic is causing significant 
socioeconomic shock in Tajikistan. ADB forecasts that GDP will contract by 0.5% in 2020.6 The 
IMF also forecasts a recession with a GDP growth rate of 1%. Revenue shortfalls equivalent to 
2.2% of GDP will expand the fiscal deficit to 6.0% of GDP, and the currency was devalued by 
6.4%. The key transmission mechanisms are a sharp reduction in remittances, international trade, 
and foreign direct investment; and slowdowns in the transport, tourism, retail, and finance 
industries. The health sector is not well equipped to respond to a large-scale health crisis, and 
unemployment and poverty are expected to rise. The power subsector as one of the backbones 
of the economy is also negatively impacted by these economic challenges, especially by reduced 
demand and lower bill collection rates. Improving the subsector’s performance by tackling key 
issues (paras. 5–10) has become more important to avoid further constraint on the country’s 
macroeconomy and reduce the economic loss.  
 
5.  Power subsector’s debt crisis. Joint Stock Holding Company Barqi Tojik has run 
Tajikistan’s power subsector since 1999. In 2019, it had 6,473 megawatts (MW) of installed 
generation capacity, of which 5,758 MW was hydro and 715 MW was thermal. Tajikistan’s 
electricity system was part of the Central Asian Power System, a regional network connecting 
Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. In 2009, after a 
regional blackout, the Tajik system was disconnected from the Central Asian Power System. 
Forced to run independently despite its dependence on the regional connections, Barqi Tojik 
urgently needed to invest in its infrastructure, especially in generation and transmission. Grants 
and loans from development partners such as ADB, the European Bank for Reconstruction and 
Development (EBRD), the World Bank, and bilateral official agencies were mobilized to support 
this effort. By 2018, Barqi Tojik had built a unified national grid with an international standard 
supervisory control and data acquisition system, and largely overcame its winter power shortage. 
 
6.  The rapid investments, however, led to a sharp increase in Barqi Tojik’s liabilities as the 
government re-lent all grants and loans from development partners with a premium of 1%–8%. 
Faced with a serious cash shortage, Barqi Tojik also kept incurring liabilities as payables to 
independent  power  producers  and  from  commercial  borrowing.  Its  total  liabilities  stood  at 
$2.7 billion by the end of 2018, of which $1.3 billion was re-lent debt from the government and 
$0.2 billion was a commercial loan, all in foreign exchange. The depreciation of the somoni by 
about 46% between 2014 and 2018 increased the impact of these liabilities and the associated 
interest payments on Barqi Tojik.   
 
7.  Moreover, Tajikistan’s economy remains vulnerable given its close correlation with the 
business cycles of key trading partners, low savings, and large needs for job creation. To ensure 
the population’s access to electricity in the challenging economic environment, the government 
has kept power prices low with limited increases (para. 8). Yet the government lacks resources 
to  fill  the  gap  between  costs  and  end-user  prices,  borne  by  Barqi  Tojik.  This  problem  is 
exacerbated by low collections from customers. The combination of constrained revenues and 
mounting liabilities has led to Barqi Tojik’s negative equity status since 2015. 
 
8.  Weak regulations and inadequate tariffs. In response to the financial issues of Barqi 
Tojik, the government increased end-user electricity tariffs by 15% on average each year during 
2014–2019. However, Tajikistan’s electricity tariffs are still some of the lowest in the world and do 
not cover the costs. Further, without a sector regulator or a tariff methodology, Barqi Tojik has not 
been required or incentivized to reveal the true cost of electricity supply. For example, its system

losses are only indicative and not based on measured data. These factors have led to large losses 
with unidentified sources for Barqi Tojik. 
 
9.  Structural corporate governance issues. The government attempted to improve Barqi 
Tojik’s operations through more effective corporate governance by replacing the company’s 
chairpersons. However, this has not improved corporate governance or performance, and the 
government set up two supervisory boards, which have managed Barqi Tojik since 2011—(i) the 
budget management supervisory board, led by the prime minister, approves Barqi Tojik’s monthly 
budgets; and (ii) the reform supervisory board, led by the first deputy prime minister, oversees 
the unbundling process. While some progress was made, Barqi Tojik needs to have an adequate 
management structure of its own to achieve financial sustainability. Advisory consulting support 
from development partners also had a limited impact on corporate governance. Furthermore, with 
investment needs estimated at $6.0 billion to improve the obsolete infrastructure system,7 public 
financing will not be enough, and the power subsector needs much wider private participation. To 
achieve this, it has to shift from government-led operations to a more market-based structure. The 
SOPI program produced a road map in 2016 for the development of an electricity trading market 
with unbundled utilities. Based on this road map, the government in April 2018 issued a decree 
to establish the joint stock companies Electric Transmission Network and Electric Distribution 
Network (EDN)8 and keep the generation function at Barqi Tojik. However, to avoid supply 
interruption, Barqi Tojik has stayed in control of sector operations, and the two new companies 
were not operationalized as independent companies. In addition, the lack of female employment 
remains a serious challenge—women account for only 12% of the 11,074 employees of Barqi 
Tojik, and hold only 11% of managerial positions.   
 
10.  Inadequate metering system. Accurately tracking power flows is key to performance 
monitoring, and it requires adequate metering both at the wholesale and retail levels. Barqi Tojik 
and feasibility study consultants estimated the transmission and distribution system losses at 22% 
and the collection rate at 86% in 2017. However, in most parts of Tajikistan, the customer 
database is incomplete; the number of meters is insufficient; and meters are 30–40 years old, 
inaccurate, and manually read, all of which makes such estimates unreliable. At the wholesale 
level, ADB is providing support to install a metering system by 2021.9 At the retail level, Barqi 
Tojik, with EBRD financing, installed advanced metering infrastructure in the Sugd Region, home 
to Tajikistan's second largest city by population, Khujand, and improved collection from 80% in 
2015 to 100% in 2018. The government plans to roll out advanced retail metering to the whole 
country and started a pilot in one of the four districts in Dushanbe, but Barqi Tojik's fragile financial 
position has constrained progress. 
 
B.  Program Description 
 
11.  The government’s efforts to restore the financial sustainability of the power subsector 
included annual tariff increases, the revival of exports to Uzbekistan in 2018,10 and investments 
in metering and billing systems in Sugd. While these have had positive impacts, Barqi Tojik’s 
financial condition continued to deteriorate, calling for more fundamental and comprehensive 
reforms.  Given  the  urgency  of  the  situation,  the  government  (i)  started  accelerating  the 
implementation of reforms based on a market development report prepared by the SOPI program 
in 2016; (ii) requested ADB, the EBRD and the World Bank to support the reform actions; and

(iii) prepared a joint reform program in 2019. The reform agenda was also coordinated with the 
IMF and included in their program discussions with the government. The reforms focus on five 
output areas—outputs 1 and 2 cover the main policy component, outputs 3 and 4 combine policy 
and project elements, and output 5 is the main project component.11 The policy component 
includes the post-program partnership framework (PPPF) under which the government will further 
deepen the reform impacts.  
 
12.  Output  1:  Power  subsector  governance  structure  strengthened  (policy).  As the 
subsector aims to develop a more commercialized structure based on the market development 
road map, unbundling needs to be completed urgently. The segmentation of the subsector 
operations into three companies (para. 9) will lead to clearer responsibilities for losses and 
inefficiencies among them and facilitate the adoption of the cost-based tariff methodology (para. 
13). To accelerate this process, the government issued four decrees between January 2019 and 
November 2020 to (i) approve the charters of the new companies, (ii) establish each company’s 
supervisory board as a governing body, (iii) complete the transfer of assets to each company, and 
(iv) appoint the chairpersons to start the operations as separate companies. The unbundling into 
smaller  companies  will  also  make  it  easier to conduct  a  gender  analysis  and  identify the 
improvements needed in human resources development—e.g., in recruitment, training, and 
employee  welfare—to  support  the  employment  and  promotion  of  women  in  technical  and 
managerial positions.   
 
13.  The replacement of one vertically integrated power utility with multiple entities requires 
more stringent sector regulations. In 2019, the government adopted a grid code for the first time 
as the subsector’s system operation rules, established a regulator to strengthen the sector’s 
governance structure, and adopted a cost-based tariff methodology. The regulator will initially be 
housed in the Anti-monopoly Agency and focus on implementing the new tariff methodology.12 As 
the regulator acquires more experience, it is planned for it to play an increasingly important role 
as an oversight and licensing body, providing a more predictable and consistent regulatory 
environment, especially as more private sector participation is introduced. Through the PPPF, the 
regulator and the unbundled companies will start the tariff determination process based on the 
new methodology. This will also set the stage for the next step of market development, the 
formulation of commercial agreements between the unbundled companies in the PPPF.  
 
14.  Output  2:  Financial  management  of  power  utilities  improved  (policy).  Foreign 
exchange-denominated liabilities are among the key causes of financial distress of Barqi Tojik. 
As of 2018, Barqi Tojik had total loans of about TJS14 billion ($1.5 billion), of which TJS12 billion 
($1.3 billion) originated from development partners’ loans and grants. In the past, the government 
re-lent all ADB project grants to Barqi Tojik with a 5% premium, and these grants account for 
about 16% of total loans. Reducing the dollar-denominated liabilities is vital for decreasing foreign 
exchange exposure, which wiped out about 80% of revenues since 2015, and for improving cash 
management in the subsector. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Ministry of Energy and 
Water Resources (MOEWR) coordinated on devising financial recovery measures since 2018, 
and the government converted more than $400 million of existing loans based on past ADB and 
World Bank project grants into Barqi Tojik equity in 2020. The remaining grant-based re-lending 
will also be gradually converted into Barqi Tojik equity by 2025, which will be monitored through

15.  The reform program also redesigns the fund flow in the subsector. A government decree 
to establish a sector escrow account to collect all domestic power sale revenues is being finalized. 
Another account for export revenues will be established before the ongoing Central Asia–South 
Asia Electricity Transmission Project (CASA–1000), supported by various development partners, 
reaches  commissioning  in  2022.  Escrow  account  activities  will  be  managed  by  a  newly 
established market operator with a predetermined fund distribution formula. These accounts will 
capture all cash inflows to the subsector to minimize human involvement and automate fund 
transfers  to  ensure  on-time  priority  payments  and  sufficient  fund  distribution  among  the 
generation, transmission, and distribution companies. It will also guarantee timely payments 
under restructured liabilities.14  
 
16.  Completion of the policy action for the escrow account mechanism (policy action 5) was 
delayed because the government functions were directly affected and slowed down by the 
COVID-19 pandemic since May 2020. This pushed the preparation process into the period of the 
presidential election (October 2020), when government functions were further slowed down. 
Therefore, the government cannot complete this action before November 2020, nonetheless, the 
government is prioritizing the action to complete it within 2020. In light of these extraordinary 
challenges, the completion of this action has been included in the policy-based grant agreement 
as a condition for withdrawal. Once the government decree is executed, transactions based on 
the escrow account will be monitored and reported through the PPPF.  
 
17.  Output 3: Sustainable corporate management introduced in the new distribution 
company (policy and project). EDN will recruit a management contractor, an internationally 
reputable company with power utility operation experience, which will place five professional 
managers in EDN to operate it (unlike the advisory roles of consultants in the past) and improve 
its corporate governance. Acting on the recommendation of the SOPI road map in 2016, the 
MOEWR led extensive consultations within the government and with development partners on 
the use of a management contract. In June 2018, 14 development partners jointly endorsed the 
reform strategy, including the use of a management contract.15 In September 2019, the ministry 
received the government’s final approval to adopt the modality as part of the program’s policy 
component. The program’s project component will finance the cost of the management contractor. 
This will be one of the first public–private partnership cases in the subsector and will be key to 
ensuring the sustainability of the reforms and the new metering investment. The contractor will 
also develop the capacity of local staff, including future managers of the company after the 
contract is completed. Further, the contractor will be tasked to create a gender working group led 
by senior management and consisting of both male and female representatives of various job 
levels and departments. This group will be responsible for incorporating gender in the strategic 
directions and organizational functions of the company.

18.  An enabling environment will be key to the success of the management contract. Given 
the current lack of transparent data from Barqi Tojik, the contractor will be given the first year to 
assess  EDN’s  infrastructure,  capacity,  and  regulatory  status  and  to  propose  operation 
improvement plans with binding performance indicators. The indicators are linked with bonuses 
as  the  contractor’s  incentives.  EDN’s  supervisory  board  will  also  allow  for  adjustments  to 
constraints beyond the contractor’s control, such as the government-set tariffs. A list of strategic 
entities will be agreed among the government, the supervisory board, and the contractor, such as 
entities with public service obligations, which will be given longer payment periods. But any 
violation of the special rules will allow the contractor to discontinue its services to them. The key 
development partners such as ADB, the EBRD and the World Bank will be observers on EDN’s 
supervisory board and receive monitoring results. The contract also includes a dispute settlement 
mechanism by a third-party panel of experts so that any issues would have a better chance of 
resolution before escalating into disputes. Finally, a separate ADB TA will finance supervision 
assistance through the Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility (para. 32) in the form of three 
independent advisors, which will strengthen implementation monitoring as designed in the PPPF.  
 
19.  Output 4: Sector’s reform and operational capacity strengthened (policy and project). 
Guided by the success of the SOPI program, the program’s project component includes a 
recruitment of a consulting firm to support the government’s further reforms. This will help the 
implementation of the PPPF as part of the program’s policy component, which includes the next 
phase of the unbundling process such as finalizing opening balance sheets and commercial 
contracts based on regulator-set tariffs, and completion of the restructuring of loans from MOF. 
The consulting firm will also closely monitor the implementation with regard to the escrow account, 
the regulator, the tariff methodology, and the management contractor performance. 
 
20.  Furthermore,  the  comprehensive  reforms  present  an  unprecedented  opportunity  for 
stepping up gender development in the subsector. The attached TA (para. 33) will support the 
unbundled companies in conducting gender assessments and creating an employee database 
that  will  inform  policies  and  training  on  corporate  gender  mainstreaming  (para.  12).  The 
management contractor’s tasks also include the establishment of a gender working group in EDN 
(para. 17) to develop policies and training on the prevention of sexual harassment. The metering 
investment will provide more opportunities for women's employment, especially at the data and 
call centers. The attached TA will also provide internship and training grants to selected women 
trainees. In addition, an ongoing ADB grant in the education sector will establish a technical skills 
development center for the energy sector with a focus on increased female employment.16 The 
improved gender policies of the key employers in the energy sector and the skills development 
opportunities will create synergy and amplify the effect of the gender action plans of both projects.  
 
21.  Output 5: Retail billing and collection systems modernized (project). The program’s 
project component will finance investments in advanced retail electricity metering and low- and 
medium-voltage grid enhancements in seven priority cities (Buston, Dangara, Dushanbe, Isfara, 
Istravshan, Konibodom, and Panjekent), which were selected based on the urgency of collection 
improvements. The planned installation of about 370,000 meters will cover close to 40% of the 
customer base and demand. Dushanbe accounts for nearly 25% of the country’s electricity sales, 
making improved revenue collection there a top priority for the subsector. The advanced metering 
and billing system will reduce the cost of metering and billing, lower outage costs, and improve 
the quality of supply for customers (e.g., faster outage restoration and more precise dispatching 
of repair crews to the sites of network breakdowns). It will also allow the introduction of new billing 
schemes, such as step tariffs, to protect vulnerable customers in newly metered cities.

power subsector.17 The program is aligned with the impact of sustainable access to energy 
resources.18 It targets an improved nationwide collection rate of 91% by 2027 against 86% in

C.  Value Added by ADB  
 
23.  ADB’s SOPI program under the Regional Power Transmission Project (footnote 2) has 
supported  the  reform  activities  since  2012.  Its  market  development  report  in  2016  is  the

SOPI platform for development partner coordination, which led to the formulation of the joint 
reform program. The proposed program will support the upfront policy actions, and its sector 
reform support component (output 4) and the World Bank’s program-for-result grant (footnote 13) 
will assist and provide incentives for the continued implementation of the policy actions. An ADB-
funded feasibility study paved the way for the EBRD to cofinance the metering investment, which

24.  The financial crisis in the Tajik power subsector is profound and recovery requires actions 
that simultaneously address sector governance, debts, tariffs, and management. Yet the impact 
will be limited without improving the accuracy in sales, timely collections, and system losses, and 
this can only be achieved by investments in adequate metering and billing systems. In turn, any 
investments in the subsector also require much improved corporate governance for the unbundled 
utility companies to be sustainable. The sector development program approach is used to support, 
through the policy-based component, structural reforms that create an enabling environment for 
financial  sustainability,  and  to  respond,  through  the  project  component,  to  the  investment 
challenges in the power subsector. Since the near-term priority of the subsector will be the 
implementation and deepening of the major reforms completed under this program, a stand-alone 
policy component with PPPF and implementation support (output 4) was selected.

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
34.  Under the SOPI program, EDN commissioned a feasibility study for metering and network 
upgrades in seven cities. The study reviewed international practice, identified technical options 
suitable for EDN, prepared the technical design, identified project benefits and costs, and 
presented an implementation plan. The study confirmed that (i) the project was in line with 
worldwide utility practice, (ii) the equipment and systems were proven and widely available, and 
(iii) EDN staff had proven their capability to operate such systems based on their experience with 
a project using the same technology in the Sugd region. The cost estimates were updated in June 
2020, considering the global impact of COVID-19. Further, EDN is the former distribution arm of 
Barqi Tojik and has run the system since 2008, thus having sufficient experience and capacity for 
developing and operating the distribution system. ADB is satisfied with the proposed technology 
and implementation plan, and EDN’s ability to operate the system. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
35.  Economic  and  financial  analyses  of  the  metering  investment  were  conducted.  The 
investment covers the capital city of Dushanbe and other priority cities in Tajikistan. Improvements 
in collections and a reduction in system losses in these cities are critical to the financial recovery 
of the subsector. The investment is expected to increase the collection rate by 8 percentage points 
and reduce system losses by 7.9 percentage points collectively in the target cities. Given the 
limited size and the current low quality of the power distribution system, assessments conclude 
that these improvements are reasonable compared with systems of similar size and condition.  
 
36.  With these assumptions, the financial internal rate of return, estimated from EDN’s 
perspective, is 14.4%, above EDN’s estimated weighted average cost of capital of 5.0%. The 
economic internal rate of return, estimated from the Tajik economy’s perspective, is 12.0%, higher 
than the threshold of 9.0%. Sensitivity analyses also supported the financial and economic 
viability of the investment.

This will be monitored through the engagement of consultants for the MOEWR through sector

D.  Governance 
 
38.  Anticorruption measures. ADB's Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the government and EDN. Consistent with its commitment to 
good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly 
or through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to 
the program. To support these efforts, the applicable provisions of ADB's Anticorruption Policy 
are included in the bidding documents. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB under the 
project component shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the 
records and accounts of the executing and implementing agencies, and of all contractors, 
suppliers, consultants, and other service providers related to the project component. Entity-level 
integrity due diligence conducted on EDN found no significant integrity risks.27 Integrity due 
diligence of EDN board members and senior managers will be done once they are appointed. 
 
39.  Financial  management.  The  financial  management  assessment  was  conducted  in 
accordance with ADB’s guidelines and concludes that EDN’s overall financial management risk 
is high. The key risks relate to the weaknesses of Barqi Tojik that EDN inherits. Issues reported 
in the 2018 audited financial statements—concerning (i) valuation of inventory, revaluation of 
assets, records on account receivables and payables, and data conciliation of revenues; (ii) lack 
of an effective internal audit function and information technology system;and (iii) inconsistent data 
consolidation  of  30  subordinate  entities—will  require  resolution.  A  timebound  financial 
management action plan was prepared to mitigate the identified risks and was agreed among 
ADB, EDN, and the MOEWR as described in the PAM. The management contractor, the project 
implementation consultants, and the sector reform support component will provide necessary 
assistance in the implementation. The financial management risk will continue to be monitored as 
EDN’s operation is established with the management contractor.   
 
40.  Procurement. The procurement capacities of the MOEWR, EDN, and the PMU were 
assessed and do not pose a significant risk to project implementation. The MOEWR has previous 
experience from recruiting and managing the SOPI consultants. While EDN is a new entity, its 
workforce comes directly from Barqi Tojik. EDN also works with the government PMU dedicated 
to energy sector projects, which has performed well in the ongoing ADB-funded projects. The 
procurement methods are selected to align with the needs of each package. Value for money with 
regard to the procurement of smart meters will be achieved through (i) a single contract package 
to  be  tendered  internationally,  (ii)  the  one-stage  procurement  method,  and  (iii) the  lowest 
evaluated cost as qualification criterion. As regards the selection of the management contractor, 
the value for money lies in (i) market outreach, (ii) fixed budget selection, and (iii) use of a fit-for-
purpose form of contract, and for the extension of the billing system, direct contracting applies.
